importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication, marking the most recent update in the ongoing postseason series between the Mariners and Blue Jays.
The year the Mariners defeated the Yankees in the ALDS, a pivotal moment believed to have saved baseball in Seattle, setting historical context for the franchise's postseason legacy.
The year of the 2001 ALCS, when Bret Boone hit a game-tying homer in Game 4, a moment referenced to show the rarity of such dramatic postseason homers in Mariners history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The current moment of the postseason series, highlighting the Mariners' progression toward their first World Series appearance in over two decades.
The span from 1995 to 2001 represents a period of sustained effort and near-misses for the Mariners, reinforcing the emotional and historical significance of their current momentum.

keyTakeAways: Eugenio Suárez hit a grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, the second in Mariners postseason history, giving Seattle a 6-2 win over the Toronto Blue Jays.
The Mariners now lead the series 3-2 and are just one win away from their first World Series appearance in franchise history.
The Mariners have never made it to the Fall Classic, making this achievement historically significant and emotionally resonant for fans.
Cal Raleigh's eighth-inning home run, tied with Aaron Judge for most in a single AL season, marks a rare and memorable moment in Mariners playoff history.
The victory follows a dramatic series of close plays, including a double play and multiple tied games, underscoring the team's resilience and rising momentum.

namedEntities.name: Eugenio Suárez
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Suárez's grand slam in the eighth inning was the pivotal play that shifted the series momentum and brought the Mariners within one win of their first World Series appearance.

namedEntities.name: Seattle Mariners
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Mariners are on the cusp of their first World Series appearance in franchise history after a dramatic playoff win, making this moment a turning point in their long-standing postseason absence.

namedEntities.name: Toronto Blue Jays
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The Blue Jays are the opposing team in the playoff series, having tied the series earlier and now facing a critical game in Toronto, representing the competitive challenge the Mariners are overcoming.

namedEntities.name: Bryce Miller
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Miller was removed in the fifth inning, allowing the Blue Jays to score and tie the game, highlighting a critical moment that set the stage for the Mariners' comeback.

namedEntities.name: Cal Raleigh
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh's eighth-inning home run tied the game and was a rare moment in playoff history, contributing to the Mariners' momentum and signaling a breakthrough in franchise playoff history.

namedEntities.name: George Springer
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Springer's two-out double in the fifth inning drove in a run, helping to tie the game and demonstrate the team's resilience during a tight series.

namedEntities.name: Ernie Clement
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Clement's single in the sixth inning drove in a run, contributing to the Mariners' scoring in a tightly contested series.

namedEntities.name: Addison Barger
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Barger was driven in by George Springer in the fifth inning, contributing to the team's ability to stay competitive in the series.

namedEntities.name: Alejando Kirk
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Kirk was driven in by Ernie Clement, adding to the Mariners' scoring in a pivotal game.

namedEntities.name: Aaron Judge
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Raleigh is tied with Judge for the most home runs in a single AL season, highlighting a notable milestone in baseball statistics and showing the significance of Raleigh’s performance.

namedEntities.name: Bret Boone
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Boone’s 2001 ALCS homer is referenced as a historical benchmark, showing the rarity of such late-in-the-game homers in Mariners playoff history.

namedEntities.name: Dan Wilson
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Wilson led the team through the playoff push and commented on the emotional and historic impact of Suárez’s grand slam and the fans’ reaction.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Eugenio Suárez hit a historic grand slam in the bottom of the eighth inning, giving the Seattle Mariners a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Blue Jays and putting them just one win away from their first World Series appearance in franchise history. The Mariners, who have never made it to the Fall Classic, are now leading the series 3-2, having overcome a series of tight and dramatic games, including key contributions from Cal Raleigh’s eighth-inning home run and multiple team players. The moment is emotionally and historically significant, echoing past near-misses from 1995 and 2001, and marking a turning point in the team’s long-standing playoff journey.
title: Eugenio Suárez grand slam powers Seattle Mariners to within one win of first World Series
